explanations.A: I think you have rounded the conversion to 3cm rather than 2.5cm. We need to multiply 20 by 2.5
explanations.B: I think you have multiplied by 2, and then added 0.5. Instead we need to multiply by 2.5. So we need 2 and a half lots of 20
explanations.C: I think you have added the numbers together, but if we know that there are 2.5cm in every inch how would we find how many cm there are in 20 inches?

explanations.A: I think you have multiplied by 2, and then added 0.5. Instead we need to multiply by 2.5. So we need 2 and a half lots of 12
explanations.B: I think you have rounded the conversion to 3cm rather than 2.5cm. We need to multiply 12 by 2.5
explanations.C: If there are 2.5cm in every inch then we need to multiply 2.5 by 12 to find how many cm there are in 12 inches. 2 lots of 12 are 24. Half of 12 is 6. When we add these together we get 30cm.
explanations.D: I think you have added the numbers together, but if we know that there are 2.5cm in every inch how would we find how many cm there are in 12 inches?

explanations.A: There are 100² = 10,000 cm² in 1 m², so we divide 600 by 10,000 to get 0.06 m².
explanations.B: I think you have multiplied, rather than divided. If we are measuring using a larger unit then we will need less of them. Also watch out for the squared symbol on the units. What does this mean?
explanations.C: You have converted from cm to m, but we need to convert from cm² to m². This means we need to multiply by the square of our normal scale factor
explanations.D: Not quite. Start by thinking about how we would normally convert between cm and m. How does this change if we are converting between cm² to m²?

explanations.A: This would only work if there were 100 minutes in an hour. How many minutes are there in an hour?
explanations.B: I think you have converted 0.3 hours to 3 minutes, but that is not quite right. 0.3 means 3/10. Start by finding 1/10 of an hour in minutes
explanations.C: As there are 60 minutes in an hour we need to multiply 1.3 by 60. This gives us 78 minutes. If you are finding the 0.3 of an hour tricky then try thinking of it as 3/10 of an hour
explanations.D: I think you have converted 0.3 hours to 30 minutes, but that is not quite right. 0.3 means 3/10 of an hour. Start by finding 1/10 of an hour in minutes

explanations.B: I think you have converted 0.4 hours to 40 minutes, but that is not quite right. 0.4 means 4/10 of an hour. Start by finding 1/10 of an hour in minutes
explanations.C: This would only work if there were 100 minutes in an hour. How many minutes are there in an hour?
explanations.D: I think you have converted 0.4 hours to 4 minutes, but that is not quite right. 0.4 means 4/10 of an hour. Start by finding 1/10 of an hour in minutes

explanations.A: I think you have divided by 4. If 5 miles = 8 kilometres would we expect 20 miles to give us a smaller number of kilometres?
explanations.B: I think you have added, but we instead need to multiply our values. What would we need to multiply 5 miles by to get to 20 miles?
explanations.C: As the scale factor is 20/5 = 4, we multiply 8 by 4 to get 32 km.
explanations.D: I think you have multiplied one too many numbers together! How many 5 miles are there in 20 miles? So how many lots of 8km would that be?

explanations.A: As the scale factor is 40/5 = 8, we multiply 8 by 8 to get 64 km.
explanations.B: You have converted from km to miles, but here we have been given the miles and we need to find the kilometres.
explanations.C: I think you have added, but we instead need to multiply our values. What would we need to multiply 5 miles by to get to 40 miles?
explanations.D: Kilometres and Miles are not the same so 40 miles cannot be the same as 40 kilometres

explanations.A: If you are measuring the height of something it cannot be less than zero. Try to think of some negative examples of these in real life
explanations.B: Temperature is the only measure which can be negative.
explanations.C: If you are measuring the length of something it cannot be less than zero. Try to think of some negative examples of these in real life
explanations.D: If you are measuring the mass of something it cannot be less than zero. Try to think of some negative examples of these in real life

explanations.A: Think carefully about the negative sign in front of the 6. Could a height be negative?
explanations.B: Think carefully about the negative sign in front of the 6. Could a mass be negative?
explanations.C: Think carefully about the negative sign in front of the 6. Could a length be negative?
explanations.D: This is the only possible answer, as it is the only measurement that can be negative.
